Dear Google,

We understand that you are trying to promote Google+, but myself and others agree, that the changes made to the commenting system on YouTube should be reversed back to it's original format prior to November fifth, two thousand and thirteen.

Our reasons are simple, some other people may have their own reasons but mine are as follows. 
To comment for some reason requires cookies. I cannot do this on my system for some reason (and yes I am using Chrome) I am unable to enable cookies and subsequently, I cannot comment on YouTube.
Another reason is that I do not want YouTube to become a social media website. It is the worlds biggest video-sharing site already, but it is the world's worst social media website at the moment. Google+ admittedly never has the momentum it needed to be as popular and sucessful as... say Facebook, and it is a very good social media website.

Here is something that would make everyone happy: YouTube has the world's biggest audience. You get a bunch of YouTubers and have them make a commercial on Google+. It will easily become viral if you choose the right people.

-Thank You

Not sure how to reply to comments directly now sorry. Anyway someone asked "why we need sharks, won't we have more fish without them?"

The answer is pretty firmly no. One example which admittedly isn't fish but still seafood is that the Chesapeake bay oyster fishery was decimated in recent years and one of the reasons for that is because sharks were over harvested leading to an increase in cow nose rays (which the sharks eat) which then go ahead and eat all the oysters (a trophic cascade). Essentially by being at the top of the food chain sharks help to maintain the balance of lower level fish species and prevents any one species from dominating the ecosystem and out competing/eating everything else.

Hope that answered your question :-)

I have a question. How much does time "weigh"? Obviously, time does not have any mass, but it is affected by gravity. By definition weight is the force of gravity on an object, and although it might not be considered an object, it is affected by gravity according to Einstein's theory of general relativity. How much does it weigh? Can it be classified as weight? Please answer.

Wow, I owe this man my gratitude. I've had three encounters with sharks; the first was a bull shark near Cozumel, off the coast of Mexico from about 20 metres away. It was only a shape in the distance, but quite an exciting dive.
The second and best was with two white sharks pretty much at arms length near Cape Town, SA. They're magnificent creatures to see in their natural habitat, but I was very glad to be in a cage.
The final one was back home in the North Sea... A 2ft long catshark... =D
